captions.text:
JAMIE ROBINSON: Here we
are in Malibu Canyon.

We have a '69 Triumph Bonneville
and '75 slash '67
Triumph Rickman Metisse.

This is Adey, local fast guy,
and we're on a couple of
British bikes.
Welcome to Ride Apart.
[ROCK MUSIC]

JAMIE ROBINSON: Wow, Yoshi,
you have some incredible
motorcycles here.

YOSHI: I was in Japan, and I
just pick up the older bikes

and fixing, always
older bikes.

I bought maybe two brand new
bikes from [INAUDIBLE]
in my life.
Well, see, same thing.

You know, this has a
lot of character.

Every bike has a different
character.
New bike, no character.
It's very interesting.

MALE SPEAKER: So, how long have
you been doing Garage
Company now?

YOSHI: Uh, total
about 25 years.
ADEY BENNETT: How'd it start?
How'd it start?
YOSHI: Oh, just my hobby.

ADEY BENNETT: At home
in "your garage?"
YOSHI: Yeah.

ADEY BENNETT: It just got bigger
and bigger, right?
YOSHI: Just bigger and bigger.

ADEY BENNETT: Until the wife
kicked you out, right?
YOSHI: [LAUGHING]

Yeah, "get out of
here," you know.

And this one, original
chassis from 1975.

And then the engine game from
a 1963 Triumph Twin.

And they built it completely
in England, and then I

imported it about seven,
eight years ago.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I'm just
disappointed there's no oil
dripping out of the engine.

Because usually under British
bikes, there's always oil.

MALE SPEAKER: Oh, a giant
puddle underneath.
YOSHI: Sometimes it's scary.
Hey, no leak oil?
Maybe no oil.
MALE SPEAKER: Good.

ADEY BENNETT: I got my
skinny jeans on.
I'm ready, man.
Let's go.
[INAUDIBLE]

JAMIE ROBINSON: This is what
happens when we haven't got an
electric start.
[ENGINE RUMBLES]

ADEY BENNETT: Yo, I came
around this corner.

And I meant to downshift, and
I hit the rear brake.

The back end went
[SQUEALING NOISE].
And I was like, [BLEEP]
this bike, man.

JAMIE ROBINSON: That's the only
thing, man, is the gear

change and the brake being
on the wrong way.
It's got so much character.
I can't believe it.

ADEY BENNETT: I'm glad
it works for you.

Because I tried it, and I
couldn't fit on that thing.
But for you, it's perfect.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah,
it's pretty ditty.

It reminds me so much
of a real racing
bike, though, you know?
It just feels so great--

ADEY BENNETT: The states it puts
you in, I can see that.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, like when
your chin's kind of on

the tank, and the rev counter
is just bobbing up and down,
it just feels wonderful.

ADEY BENNETT: My oldest bike
is a '99 Kawasaki ZX-9.

So, riding this thing, it's
like going back in time.

It's a place I've never
been before, you know?
And it's cool.

I mean, the bike wasn't bad
once you got it going.
In the corners, it was cool.
I didn't have to brake much.

The engine braking did
everything for me.

But the shifting was a little
sketchy at first until you
explained what to do.

JAMIE ROBINSON: The thing
is, with these British

motorcycles, is just taking
your time to change gear.

Japanese bikes, modern bikes,
they rip through the gears.

ADEY BENNETT: Yeah, you
bang through it.
I'm like bam, bam, bam.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Exactly, as
quick as you can do it.

ADEY BENNETT: The bike won't
catch up to that.

JAMIE ROBINSON: But it's totally
the opposite here.

You've got to take some time,
not take it out too much on
the gear box or the engine.

And you get a few neutrals
in there, as well.
ADEY BENNETT: A few?

JAMIE ROBINSON: I've
got a few, too.

ADEY BENNETT: I had more than
a few coming up here.

JAMIE ROBINSON: And I think
that, in part, is getting used
to the gear box.

Because when I take a bit more
time, and I'm not in a rush,
it selects beautifully.

If I'm going to try and rush
it, the bike tells you
straight away.

ADEY BENNETT: Yeah, that's
what it does.

It told me that a lot of
times coming up here.

JAMIE ROBINSON: What do you
think about having to kick
start these bikes?

ADEY BENNETT: That
is such a [BLEEP]
workout.

JAMIE ROBINSON: No,
no, for me it is.
I'm doing yours.

ADEY BENNETT: I'm getting
tired watching
you start my bike.

JAMIE ROBINSON: At one time,
British bikes were at the top
of the world, you know?
ADEY BENNETT: What happened?

JAMIE ROBINSON: This is as
good as they got, man.

ADEY BENNETT: What
about the brakes?

How did you like the brakes
on this bike?
JAMIE ROBINSON: I'm amazed.
ADEY BENNETT: Really?

JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah, I've
ridden old bikes before.

But this front brake is
one or two fingers.

But they're so unique,
aren't they?

You just know that if you owned
this motorcycle, nobody
else would have one.

ADEY BENNETT: I mean, look, it
has a little side-pouch on it.
It's cool.
See, watch, first time.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Yeah!
ADEY BENNETT: Yeah, what?
First shot.
[ENGINE STALLS]

ADEY BENNETT: The way it rides,
once you get over the

vibration, I liked the way it
goes through the turns.
It was fun.

JAMIE ROBINSON: The bike
has character, man.

ADEY BENNETT: Yeah, but it's a
little bit too much character.

You got to tone it down
a little bit.

But as I got into it, and it
stayed in its position as I

was steering into the
turns, it felt
really good and natural.

I could see it could carry
a lot of corner speed.

Once you trust it, you could
go fast on this bike.

JAMIE ROBINSON: When I was
behind you on this bike, this

bike just seemed to make up so
much ground in the middle of
the corner.
Because, suddenly--

the way it feels is that
this chassis is
really a racing chassis.

And it doesn't feel happy
until you really--

ADEY BENNETT: Punch it
just as hard as it
goes through the turns.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I can't
believe this is a '69.
It's a wonderful ride.
It's so comfortable.

If I had my missus on the back
here, she'd never let me have
another motorcycle.
This is so mellow.

ADEY BENNETT: Yeah, I
was having a good
time on this bike.

JAMIE ROBINSON: And this is a
real racing-- it's a classic
racing bike, really.
ADEY BENNETT: You don't say.

I mean, I give props to the old
guys that were racing back

then, because it takes
a lot to corner.
Uh, [BLEEP]
you.

Classic, you set me up every
time with that shit.

You know what, the pressure's
on, so--
That [BLEEP]
hurt.
Is this in gear?
MALE SPEAKER: It's in gear.
ADEY BENNETT: [BLEEP]
[INAUDIBLE]
[BLEEP]--
if it kills us.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Come on, dude.

title: The booming Triumphs of Garage Company - /RideApart

comments.text:
One guy is out of his element on the older British machines, looks like he 
enjoyed the trip back in time though. I rode Norton Commandos back in the 
day, built with my own hands, a 68 Fastback and a 72 Interstate. I built 
the 68 into a cafe style like the green Triumph in this vid, and man was it 
nimble. Surprised the Bonny is running without filters on the carbs, their 
angle looks off too, they belong on that machine?﻿
comments.author: fritze01

5:50 "British bikes were once at the top of the world." " Then what

comments.author: motonut

comments.text:
+Ilan The summer I turned 16 I got my lisence on a Hodaka 100 B+, rode it 
for one week then got on a CB750K4. I couldn't imagine anything could have 
more power (around 56 hp I think) and still be legal. Now I ride an '03 
ZXR900R but I would sure love swap rides for an outing with an early 70's 
CB750. I am certain I could still recognize the distinctive music of that 
Honda from a mile away!
comments.author: rheniformer

comments.text: or the yamaha r5 who beat the triumph 500 1 or 2 or 3 or4 carb.
comments.author: Claude Fortin

comments.text:
Before the CB 750, the Japanese were already producing bikes which were 
seriously biting the ass of the unreliable British bikes, and the Italian 
were not far behind with the Guzzi V750, more oriented for touring. I 
forget the BMW 69S...The 1971 the 750 Ducati achieved what wanted a twin 
lover and we know the descendants. Thanks ingeniere Taglioni!. Aside the 
250 et 350, there were the 450 DOHC Honda largely as fast as a 650 Bonnie 
but with a erratic handling, the reliable T500 Suzuki, excellent base for a 
sport bike, but you're right the CB750 was the death of the British bikes, 
it was the dream of the 1967 500 Grand Prix put on road. The impression was 
colossal. I had one of the first pre-serie (made for homologation in the 
different countries) with the cranks casted in sand. At least 5 HP more 
than the serial one with the smooth casts. Extremely reliable, for the 
first time I could travel without having 45 pounds of tools and spare 
parts. The rear tire Dunlop K81 didn't last long, and the poor chain was 
short lived even with high maintenance but compared to the Bonnies and 
Commandos the CB750 was a total dream.
comments.author: Ilan

comments.text:
had Triumphs from 15 years old . my boss bought me my first one when I was 
15 .it cost £8 and I paid him back 10 shillings a week.. it was a 1948 T100 
. my first big  Jap bike was a K2 750 4 ..it felt like a rocket ship after 
the old Triumphs

comments.text: these dudes are havn fun..wat its all about﻿
comments.author: zion kairua

comments.text:
This video kind of gives off a negative vibe relative to kick-start-only 
bikes, but the fact is, once you've owned one for a while, you 
inadvertently discover subtle tricks that make starting a breeze. By 
tricks, I mean, for my 850 Commando, pump the throttle three times, then 
barely crack it open, push on the kicker until you feel resistance, and 
then come down on the kicker in a slow, smooth, controlled motion using 
your body weight, and it will fire right up. Stabbing at the kickstarter 
will do nothing, nor will kicking with the throttle fully closed. Open the 
throttle too much, and it will just fart... etc, etc. I own several bikes, 
both new and old, and by far my favorite - hands down - is my fully 
caffeinated '74 850 Commando. It's loud, it leaks, it smells, it vibrates, 
the speedometer needle wags like a dog's tail, the front brake is as 
effective as pressing two pieces of plywood against a rotor, and frankly, 
those are the reasons I love owning and riding it so much. Oh, and by 
comparison, I can kick my '69 Tiger 650 through with just leg muscle; the 
Commando requires all 250 lbs of me to get it to turn over. The kicker gear 
on the Triumph is much larger than that of the Norton, making starting the 
Triumph a breeze, relatively speaking. Great video; thanks guys -﻿
comments.author: Brit rider

comments.text:
I for one miss having a kick start. I once drove a 1992 Lada Niva that had 
a crank for emergency starting. It was a 1500cc 4 cylinder and astoundingly 
easy to star with the crank!
comments.author: rheniformer

comments.text:
I do understand your love for your Commando, but myself I wasn't on 1969 
enough masochist, after a disastrous experience of total unreliability with 
a 1969 Bonnie to stay on the path of the pain and suffering with English 
bikes. After a T500 Suzuki which reconciled me with motorcycles, I bought a 
used 1969 (the very very first model sand casted) CB750 and kept it 9 years 
and 122000 km with no problem, except normal maintenance. Never let me 
down, hard working for example 1000 kilometers from Hamburg to Milan in 8 
hours, including  gas/coffee/inspection tires-chain stops and the Swiss 
mountains, the engine purring all long like a happy cat. Not a drop of oil, 
not a misfire. not a leak just a very tired chain and an exhausted K81.
comments.author: Ilan

comments.text:
Hi-Yella dude seems too closed minded. There was a mechanical 'truth' to 
the bikes of the past which is why despite their faults, unreliability and 
'wonkyness', many are still thought of fondly by folks. This dude in truth 
just seems to simply be a product of the modern age to be fair..cant blame 
him for it I suppose.. Someone should walk him thru checking the points and 
how frequently it had to be done..that'll freak him out..﻿

comments.author: Claudemir Dias

comments.text:
It wasn't the XS650 that started Triumph's demise, it was the CB750 - 
electric start, over-head cams and 68 hp in stock tune, and reliable. Not 
my cup of tea for sure, but BSA and Triumph were typical of the UK 
industries at the time and were happy to make money from the public without 
investing in the future. The (original) Trident triple was too little, too 
late.﻿
comments.author: Andy W

comments.text:
I'd love to introduce those two to the T120C sitting in our garage. It was 
set up for flat track racing before we got it and I think it might have 
been taken up to 750cc and even higher compression than stock. Those 67 and 
69 have 9.8 or 9.5:1 the T120C came from the factory with 11:1 and "wild 
cams" as well as larger carbs making a wopping 52HP instead of the regular 
47HP, but I think when it was set up for racing they might've bumped the 
compression up even higher. I am 6'9 300lbs and it takes pretty much all my 
weight to kick it over and it doesn't start easily.﻿
comments.author: J.A.Ratt85

comments.text:
Don't just sit there man! Make a video of that T120C for those of us who 
are not familiar with it!

comments.author: Mike Rowave

comments.text:
@William Hoffman: I doubt a low production and unpopular XS650 had anything 
to do with Triumph's demise. It was most likely due to misappropriated 
funds that went elsewhere instead of upgrading and modernizing the bikes 
although in my opinion, they were just fine (with proper servicing)
The Yamaha copied the Triumph which doesn't really say much if the Triumph 
was so bad.
The Yamaha XS650 was so unpopular that they remained unsold for years. New 
1982's could still be had at Yamaha dealers up until 1987. OUCH!
Besides, the XS650 have/had no soul. Great dike-bikes though. Right up 
there with the Honda Rebel series.﻿
comments.author: Yamaha SR650

comments.text:
That's what buried Triumph in the 1970's. Japan offered comparable bikes 
that were more reliable with more-or-less the same looks and feel for less 
money. The XS650 sunk Triumph.
comments.author: William Hoffman

This was a cool video but out of respect for classic Brit iron you should 
at a minimum screw on some velocity stacks with fine mesh grill on the '68 
Bonnie.I can't believe the fellow who set up the Amals didn't think about 
sucking up road dust and grit. No aggression here, just genuine concern 
about raw crap getting pulled into such a righteous classic and prematurely 
destroying the top end.
comments.author: Eric Mowrey

comments.text: I envy Mr. Kosaka's talents and abilities. And his garage. Sweet!
comments.author: TheCarablanco

comments.text: 1976 Triumph T140V Bonneville for ever!
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
I will put her back on the road one day when both she and I are so old no 
one would try to prove they are faster out of respect. I raced for 10 
consecutive years from 1977 to 1987 and I went after every bike on the road 
that was trying to prove how fast they could go. Most people were bad 
mouthing Triumph and I raced them to keep Triumph in business. I beat 
everyone! It was the single greatest accomplishment of my life. I am a 
Fresco painter and a violinist and was a self tough engineer.
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
Anyway that's the story and please don't ridicule a man who put his heart 
and soul into street racing his Triumph Bonneville and absolutely risked 
death many times. My SECRET was to race the road and not the other bike in 
a road race, if you could fair and square beat me that would be fine. NO 
one ever did. I still have my Bonneville. I am not interested in racing 
anymore and now I ride cruiser bikes. I'm actually reluctant to put my 
Bonne on the road as I would rather die than suffer defeat.
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
I beat him from Nediks on the North Shore of L.I. to Southern State Pky. I 
beat him on that PKY all the way to Robert Moses Parkway on the South shore 
of L.I.. There was a long right hand curve to enter Robert Moses and I was 
afraid to lean on the right side because of the oil on my tire. He passed 
me in that curve and just out and out left me for dead as his bike was 
tremendously fast. It was night and I just went as fast as I could and I 
was practically crying as no one had yet beat my Bike.
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
con't. That guy was a f-jerk. We started out at Nediks in Comack L.I., N.Y. 
I had just done a tune up and stupid me used a ripped valve cover gasket 
and the oil pressure was forcing the oil out of the valve cover and onto 
the frame where it trickled onto my rear tire. I told him I could not race 
that night and showed him my oil wet tire. He said ok. We will ride to the 
OBI South about 12 miles south. We started out and immediately he was on 
the gas so me being me said fuck it all and raced.
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
con't. WE raced about 1/4 mi to a hair pin turn with me still leading. Then 
into a hairpin turn around where he almost T-Boned me. Then 100yds to the 
parking lot of the OBI Oak Beach Inn South and a rt. into the gravel 
parking lot. I thought he was nuts as that shit will tear you up. I arrived 
at the door and jumped off the bike with my key held in the air as he 
pulled to a stop. There was a crowd gathered and they all applauded my 
VICTORY.
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
Believe it. His bike could accelerate about twice as fast as mine. There 
was a long stretch on the Robert Moses PKY in N.Y. and across it's bridge-I 
was crying as my Bonneville was experiencing her first defeat. He got at 
least 1/2 mile ahead of me but I kept on going and did not give up. It was 
night time and LOL he had to slow down from 179mph to make the right turn 
exit. Me? I kept the throttle wide open and caught him and passed him in 
the apex, then about a 1/4 mile short strait. con't
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
I want to believe that. I want to believe it so badly, but there is just no 
way that a 76 T140 could beat out a modern-ish 1100cc sports bike. The 
latter would be making twice the power as the former! Even allowing for 
better weight and handling on the bonnie, it just wouldn't stand a chance 
against that kind of raw power.
comments.author: rexstuff

Man, you only have to look at these old bikes to realize what great 
machines motorcycles are, marvels of human ingenuity and engineering. So

comments.text:
My 1976 Triumph T140V Bonneville can shift faster than my Japanese Honda. 
With no false neutrals. I think the bike you guy's rode may have been 
"clapped out". Meaning so old that they no longer function like they were 
designed to function. BTW I beat a new 1992 Ninja 1100 fuel injected bike 
with my old Triumph in 12 mile road race.
comments.author: PeterDad60

comments.text:
At one time , ELECTRIC STARTS where wooos. A well tooned bike and 
experience made starting a production of beauty. Realy miss those days, the 
push button instant gratification bikes seem shallow these days. I agree 
that gearboxes of old worked just fine, you had to work at it to trash one. 
Thanks for the memories, you lucky dogs.

comments.author: Dharma Praksoso

comments.text:
i can see you have some lovely turns and weather. here in the uk i have 
ridden quite a few bikes in my time. one that comes to mind is the suziki 
gt750 (nickname kettle 1975) it had character but to follow those british 
bikes it would have to use both lanes with some dancing. strange how the 
early bikes did not handle but had so much power than the british bikes. I 
also had a high speed rear tyre blow out. as i slowed down two up. the rear 
was moving the whole width of the lane from side to side
comments.author: vinnychoff

comments.text:
Meant to write "the black one", If I had had something to say about the 
other guy, I would have referred to him as the "the white one". I'm not 
racist, skin colour is the easiest way to recognize them from each other. 
English isn't my native language.

well, good luck. If you get one search out every improvement that was ever

comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
OK, I give up, enjoy your HD. I look at bikes differently than you. Rode my 
first bike, a Honda S-90 (lol) @ 17 in '69. Including that, I've owned 10 
bikes total, 5 Euro motocrossers (CZ, Bultaco, KTM, DKW, and Ossa), 3 
Honda, and 2 Yamaha roadbikes - 2 Hondas were large-bore singles, 
"thumpers" that I turned into cafe racers. My 2 Yamahas were both 
variations on the RD/RZ 350/400 theme. Any bike I own has to corner, fast. 
Right now, riding nothing, hence my crankiness, sorry for the bad vibes.
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
If you're sincere, and I'll take you at your word that you are, then 
apology accepted. I've certainly said/wrote things that didn't come out 
quite like I meant it. Keep on ridin'
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
There's more to it than that. Japanese bikes got so hugely popular because 
they introduced an entirely new concept; reliability, back in the day. Even 
when new Triumph, and other english bikes of the time, were troublesome. 
That said: Of course you're right. 50 years of different owners and wear 
and tear takes its toll on any bike. The guy i knew who owned a Triumph.. 
That story is from the late 80's. The bike was, as far as i know, original, 
and now you mention it: Carbs and ignition..yeah..;)
comments.author: jo05dk

comments.text: That's what I've heard. I really want one. :-P

comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
they break down mostly according to your (in)ability to do proper wrenching 
and ability to absorb the 30 + years of people's experience in improving 
the bikes to make them more ridable without losing the original character. 
If you want to do a frame-up completely original restoration it should be 
for a bike that isn't ridden, it will be a miserable experience. Improve 
the bike as you "restore" it. That means Mikuni carbs instead of the 
horrible "Anal" carbs. Replace "Mucus" electrics, etc...
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
I worked at a Kawa shop when the H1 (500 triple) first came out. I got to 
ride a lot of them because no one else wanted to. Excellent engine, chassis 
of crap. Straight line acceleration was cool, but as soon as you were even 
close to a corner your life was in jeapordy.
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text: I do hope you're kidding.
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text: take your racist bullshit somewhere else.
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
Neither one looked like they had ever kickstarted a bike in their lives. 
That had a lot to do with it. Never had a problem starting my Brother's '67 
Bonny. Way back when I had a job at a bike shop that provided me with a 
"company bike" chosen from the used bike lot. I chose a 1970 Norton Type S 
(essentially a Commando with upswept pipes on the left) Ran great, started 
easy - got to ride it for a year.
comments.author: James Scott

comments.text:
looks like velo stacks probably with some kind of mesh screen - it's not my 
idea of how to keep an expensive engine clean inside - needs a set of K & 
N's or it'll need some top-end repair soon.
comments.author: James Scott
